natural problem: The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$
natural solution: To work with the inverse $f^{-1},$ we consider the range of each component of $f(x).$ Let $g(x) = x-2$ for $x < 4,$ and let $h(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \ge 4.$ For $x < 4,$ we have $x - 2 < 2,$ so the range of $g$ is the interval $(-\infty, -2).$ For $x \ge 4,$ we have $\sqrt{x} \ge 2,$ so the range of $h$ is $[2, \infty).$

The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. (x < 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = x - 2) \<and> (x \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = sqrt x)"
shows  "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. inv f x) = 54"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$ The final Answer is 54

 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. (x < 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = x - 2) \<and> (x \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = sqrt x)"
shows  "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. inv f x) = 54"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Given a bijective function $f$ where $f(x) = x - 2$ for $x < 4$ and $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \geq 4$. Find the sum of the inverses of $f(x)$ for $x$ in the range -5 to 5. The final answer is $54$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f_inv :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (x < 4 \<longrightarrow> (inv f) x = x - 2) \<and> (x \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> (inv f) x = sqrt x)"
shows  "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. f_inv x) = 54"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$ The final Answer is 54
 ### Proof
 To work with the inverse $f^{-1},$ we consider the range of each component of $f(x).$ Let $g(x) = x-2$ for $x < 4,$ and let $h(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \ge 4.$ For $x < 4,$ we have $x - 2 < 2,$ so the range of $g$ is the interval $(-\infty, -2).$ For $x \ge 4,$ we have $\sqrt{x} \ge 2,$ so the range of $h$ is $[2, \infty).$
 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f_inv :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. (x < 4 \<longrightarrow> (inv f) x = x - 2) \<and> (x \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> (inv f) x = sqrt x)"
shows  "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. f_inv x) = 54"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: "Find the sum of the function $f^{-1}(x)$ for all $x$ in the range from $-5$ to $5$, where $f^{-1}(x)$ is defined as $x - 2$ for $x < 4$ and $\sqrt{x}$ for $x \geq 4$. The final answer is $54$."

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real ⇒ real" and inv_f :: "real ⇒ real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. (x < 4 --> f x = x - 2) ∧ (x ≥ 4 --> f x = sqrt x)"
and h2 : "inv_f = inv f"
shows  "(∑x = -5..5. inv_f x) = 54"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$ The final Answer is 54
 ### Proof
 To work with the inverse $f^{-1},$ we consider the range of each component of $f(x).$ Let $g(x) = x-2$ for $x < 4,$ and let $h(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \ge 4.$ For $x < 4,$ we have $x - 2 < 2,$ so the range of $g$ is the interval $(-\infty, -2).$ For $x \ge 4,$ we have $\sqrt{x} \ge 2,$ so the range of $h$ is $[2, \infty).$
 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real ⇒ real" and inv_f :: "real ⇒ real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. (x < 4 --> f x = x - 2) ∧ (x ≥ 4 --> f x = sqrt x)"
and h2 : "inv_f = inv f"
shows  "(∑x = -5..5. inv_f x) = 54"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: For a function $f$, if $f(x) = x - 2$ for $x < 4$ and $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \geq 4$, and $f$ is a bijection, find the sum of the inverses of $f(x)$ for $x$ from $-5$ to $5$. The final answer is $54$.

a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$ The final Answer is 54
 ### Proof
 To work with the inverse $f^{-1},$ we consider the range of each component of $f(x).$ Let $g(x) = x-2$ for $x < 4,$ and let $h(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \ge 4.$ For $x < 4,$ we have $x - 2 < 2,$ so the range of $g$ is the interval $(-\infty, -2).$ For $x \ge 4,$ we have $\sqrt{x} \ge 2,$ so the range of $h$ is $[2, \infty).$
 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f_inv :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f_inv"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. f_inv x = (if x < 4 then x - 2 else sqrt x)"
shows  "sum f_inv {-5..5} = 54"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

(* ### Problem

 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]

theorem
fixes f_inv :: "int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> x. f_inv x = (if x < 4 then x - 2 else sqrt x)"
and h1 : "bij f_inv"
shows  "(\<Sum>x = -5..5. f_inv x) = 54"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. if x < 4 then f x = x - 2 else f x = sqrt x"
and h2 : "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. (inv f) x) = 54"
shows  "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. (inv f) x) = 54"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$ The final Answer is 54
 ### Proof
 To work with the inverse $f^{-1},$ we consider the range of each component of $f(x).$ Let $g(x) = x-2$ for $x < 4,$ and let $h(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \ge 4.$ For $x < 4,$ we have $x - 2 < 2,$ so the range of $g$ is the interval $(-\infty, -2).$ For $x \ge 4,$ we have $\sqrt{x} \ge 2,$ so the range of $h$ is $[2, \infty).$
 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. if x < 4 then f x = x - 2 else f x = sqrt x"
and h2 : "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. (inv f) x) = 54"
shows  "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. (inv f) x) = 54"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Given a bijective function $f$ defined as follows: $f(x) = x - 2$ for $x < 4$ and $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \geq 4$, find the sum of the inverse of $f$ for $x$ from $-5$ to $5$. The final answer is $54$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and f_inv :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. if x < 4 then f x = x - 2 else f x = sqrt x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f_inv x = (inv f) x"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. f_inv i) {-5..5} = 54"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$ The final Answer is 54
 ### Proof
 To work with the inverse $f^{-1},$ we consider the range of each component of $f(x).$ Let $g(x) = x-2$ for $x < 4,$ and let $h(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \ge 4.$ For $x < 4,$ we have $x - 2 < 2,$ so the range of $g$ is the interval $(-\infty, -2).$ For $x \ge 4,$ we have $\sqrt{x} \ge 2,$ so the range of $h$ is $[2, \infty).$
 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and f_inv :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. if x < 4 then f x = x - 2 else f x = sqrt x"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. f_inv x = (inv f) x"
shows  "sum (\<lambda>i. f_inv i) {-5..5} = 54"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Find the sum of the inverse function values from -5 to 5 of a function $f(x)$, which is defined as $f(x) = x - 2$ for $x < 4$ and $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \geq 4$. The final answer is 54.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x < 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = x - 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = sqrt x"
and h3 : "sum (inv f) {-5..5} = 54"
shows  "sum (inv f) {-5..5} = 54"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The function \[f(x) = \left\{ \begin{aligned} x-2 & \quad \text{ if } x < 4 \\ \sqrt{x} & \quad \text{ if } x \ge 4 \end{aligned} \right.\]has an inverse $f^{-1}.$ Find the value of $f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5).$ The final Answer is 54
 ### Proof
 To work with the inverse $f^{-1},$ we consider the range of each component of $f(x).$ Let $g(x) = x-2$ for $x < 4,$ and let $h(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \ge 4.$ For $x < 4,$ we have $x - 2 < 2,$ so the range of $g$ is the interval $(-\infty, -2).$ For $x \ge 4,$ we have $\sqrt{x} \ge 2,$ so the range of $h$ is $[2, \infty).$
 The inverse of $g$ is $g^{-1}(x) = x+2,$ while the inverse of $h$ is $h^{-1}(x) = x^2.$ To compute $f^{-1}(x),$ we must use $g^{-1}$ if $x < 2,$ and use $h^{-1}$ if $x \ge 2$: \[\begin{aligned} f^{-1}(-5) + f^{-1}(-4) + \dots + f^{-1}(4) + f^{-1}(5) &= \left(g^{-1}(-5) + \dots + g^{-1}(1)\right) + \left(h^{-1}(2) + \dots + h^{-1}(5)\right) \\ &= \left((-3) + (-2) + \dots + 3\right) + \left(4 + 9 + 16 + 25\right) \\ &= 0 + 54 \\ &= \boxed{54}.
 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes x :: real and f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall> x. x < 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = x - 2"
and h2 : "\<forall> x. x \<ge> 4 \<longrightarrow> f x = sqrt x"
and h3 : "sum (inv f) {-5..5} = 54"
shows  "sum (inv f) {-5..5} = 54"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: Given a bijective function $f$ defined as $f(x) = x - 2$ for $x < 4$ and $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ for $x \geq 4$. If the sum of the inverses of $f$ for all integers from $-5$ to $5$ is $54$, verify that this sum is indeed $54$.

a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 \end{aligned}\]
 *)

theorem
fixes f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real" and inv_f :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "bij f"
and h1 : "\<forall>x. if x < 4 then f x = x - 2 else f x = sqrt x"
and h2 : "\<forall>x. inv_f (f x) = x"
shows  "(\<Sum>x=-5..5. inv_f x) = 54"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem:
The function $f$ is defined as follows: $f(x) = x - 2$ if $x < 4$, and $f(x) = \sqrt{x}$ otherwise. The function $f$ is bijective and has an inverse function $f^{-1}$ such that $f^{-1}(f(x)) = x$. 

What is the sum of the inverses $f^{-1}(x)$ for all $x$ from -5 to 5? The final answer is 54.
